_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
Enterprise Propane Terminals and Storage Cheraw Terminal 
RMP Executive Summary

EPA ID:  1000 0016 5634

At the Enterprise Propane Terminals and Storage Cheraw Terminal we are committed to operating and maintaining our process in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.

The Enterprise Propane Terminals and Storage Cheraw Terminal is owned by Enterprise Products Operating LLC and is operated by Enterprise Propane Terminals and Storage Company. The Cheraw Terminal is a LPG pipeline terminal connected to the Dixie interstate LPG pipeline system.    The process is regulated by the OSHA Process Safety Management program for highly hazardous chemicals.

We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved
* Emergency Response Programs
* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Cheraw Terminal that are regulated by EPAA?s RMP rule.  

Facility Description

The Cheraw Terminal engages in the pipeline receipt and storage of liquefied propane under pressure, and the loading of the propane into tank trucks.    The process is regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and EPA 40 CFR Part 68.  We have registered the facility as an RMP Program Level 3 facility.

The facility receives, stores and distributes propane

LPG.  There are four storage tanks at the Cheraw Terminal, and the tanks are administratively controlled to hold and not exceed 80% of their capacity.  The facility consists of pressure storage tanks, liquid propane dehydrators, a truck loading dock, mercaptan injection system and associated piping, valves and other miscellaneous equipment.  The process and storage is a wholesale product distribution terminal for propane LPG.    

In our process we use the following chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

There are no toxic materials contained on site above the threshold limits.

Flammables

Propane is a finished product which is received into four storage tanks.  This material is routed from these tanks to the loading docks for distribution.  A small quantity of ethyl mercaptan is stored at the terminal for propane odorization.  The stored quantity is below the threshold quantity specified in the RMP Rule.

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

Worst Case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemical

No toxic material above the threshold quantity is present at the Cheraw Terminal.

Alternate Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemical

No toxic material above the threshold quantity is present at the Cheraw Terminal. 

Worse Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals


The Cheraw Terminal Risk Management Program registration includes information on a worst case scenario calculated according to the requirements of the RMP regulation.   All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the Risk Management Plan registration

Alternate Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

An alternate release scenario has been determined and the possible co

nsequences calculated for the Cheraw Terminal.  Details of the alternate case scenario and the endpoint of the simulation are contained in the RMP registration.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting and estimating the effects of  the alternative release scenario.   Activation of the terminal Emergency Shutdown System and devices would isolate the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if the assumed or any other alternate release were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation are contained in the RMP registration data elements. 

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Chesterfield County Sheriff's Department Emergency Management District, which includes the local Cheraw Police department, Chesterfield County Sheriff's Department, Cheraw Fire Department, and Emergency Medical Service.

In the event of an accidental release, local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the alarm, shut off the source from a safe location and contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the local Police and Fire Departments.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Enterprise takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management systems addr

ess each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The following is a list of improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

* The accident prevention/PSM program is currently undergoing a complete review and revision to provide an updated program which complies with the requirements of the PSM Standard and can be fully implemented at the diverse number of facilities in the Enterprise partnership.
* A fire detection system is planned for installation at Cheraw Terminal to automatically shut down the facilty in case of a fire.  
.
